item.title: Lessons Learned About Landing a Job in Boulder
item.description:
[caption id="attachment_2868" align="aligncenter" width="332"] A job to let me land safely...can you tell I had trouble with the image for this post?[/caption]

I'm happy to announce that I have finally landed a job in Boulder, which means that I can stay.

As you know, keeping upbeat in the face of difficult prospects has been hard. Especially going into March, which would have been the limit of my savings, I was worried I was going to hit a wall.

Luckily, just as I reached the end of my financial rope, a job came through. Funny how that works.

Of course, now I have the issue of having too many things to do.

In addition to the usual workaday job at the grocery store, I was also given my first tutoring assignment, and landed my first paid freelance magazine article.

Coaching MovNat is still my preferred form of employment, but that hasn't resulted in any paying arrangements. However, I'm still giving it as much attention as I can spare, going around to gyms and studios offering to run workshops and introduce myself to as wide an audience as possible.

My guess is that I will use the consistent job to get established while developing more lucrative opportunities that allow me to work on my own time.

This period of my life is certainly one of the most challenging and uncomfortable, but I can tell it is also fostering a lot of growth. It's the kind of uncomfortable experience that you know is good for you, even if you'd rather not have to go through it. Sort of like exercise (which I guess I'm fairly good at).

Here are a few short lessons I've learned:

item.title: Guilt by Association; Chained to the Wrong Job
item.description:
"There Is A Voice Inside Of You
That Whispers All Day Long,
"I Feel That This Is Right For Me,
I Know That This Is Wrong."
No Teacher, Preacher, Parent, Friend
Or Wise Man Can Decide
What's Right For You- Just Listen To
The Voice That Speaks Inside." - Shel Silverstein

Today, my employer did something that got me really angry. I'm not going to go into details, because even though she doesn't read English and I wouldn't mind that much if I got fired at this point, it would still be kind of underhanded to do it publicly.

However, today's events did teach me a very important lesson about integrity: When I work for someone, a group, or a company, I need to make sure their values are in line with my own, otherwise I risk putting my efforts and energy into causes that I either don't care about, or that I am totally opposed to.

When you work for an organization, your efforts are directed towards achieving that organization's ends. Sometimes, this is great. With the multiplier effect of a dedicated community, your small contribution can have much larger effects than it otherwise would.

On the other hand, if you don't agree with what your organization is doing, then your energy is applied to something you would otherwise oppose.

This is why Awareness is extremely important in ensuring that you live the life you want. If you don't pay attention to the implications of your actions, then you end up being taken for a ride.
